title: How to write an entire book on a tablet - Quora

response.answer_text: Think of your tablet as a computer first and foremost. Now, work out what you’ll need to accomplish in order to write an entire book. Research.Organizing your research materials.Viewing your research materials.ideation.Organizing your ideation.Writing.Reading what you’ve written.Manipulating what you’ve written.Analyzing your text.Redrafting.Collaborating with an editor.Find apps that run on your particular tablet that are good for the tasks mentioned above. Things like OneNote and Evernote run on pretty much any tablet, and can be used for organizing material. Find some sort of outlining tool or mindmapping app for you to do your ideation on. Find a decent word processor app to do your writing, analysis, and redrafting on. Maybe Google Docs will do the trick. Maybe something else. Doesn’t matter what it is, as long as you can do what you need to do in the app. Lastly, get yourself an external keyboard and mouse, and something that will let you prop the tablet into a comfortable reading and writing position on your desk. Be ergonomically-minded. Writing is a beast. Expect sessions to last anywhere between an hour and three hours. Take frequent breaks. If your setup isn’t ergnomically viable, you’ll soon be in too much pain to write anything, and you’ll rue the day your started your book. Remember the motto that writing is rewriting. But also remember that rewriting comes AFTER writing, not DURING writing. Do not edit until you’re finished your first draft. I finished my novel by following the advice of a writer called Donna Levin. Her book, GET THAT NOVEL STARTED! (AND KEEP IT GOING ’TIL YOU FINISH), advised me to sit down for no fewer than 10 minutes EVERY day, including Sundays, and write during those sessions. It works. (Some days, you’ll write for ten minutes. Other days, you’ll burn three hours without even realizing it.) A book is ready to be read by someone other than yourself only after AT LEAST the third draft, preferably the fifth. Redrafting is very very very fricking hard. Harder than writing the first draft. Be prepared for this. Good luck with your book!

Heya thanks for the A2A. BLUETOOTH KEYBOARD! Seriously, that's how I did it. (Okay, I didn’t finish anything, but I did a lot of work on one). I didn’t have a laptop for 4 or 5 years? A long time and I didn’t feel like I needed one. I had a tablet and a Bluetooth keyboard. Google Docs didn’t cope so well on tablets back then, so I downloaded an app called ‘writer’ and used that instead. I actually found writing on a tablet much easier too, there was less to distract me, and it was easily transportable. I could crack it open and work on my stories when and where ever, and I often did. In fact, I recently brought a new tablet, because of how much more convenient it is to carry around and bring out whenever. Waiting for coffee? Do some writing, on a bus? break out the tablet. I used to hide it under the bench at work, so when it was quiet I could work on my stories. (It happened often). So how do you write an entire book on a tablet? Get yourself a keyboard - unless you like typing on a screen, then you don’t need one. Then find yourself a writing platform. I like google docs because it autosaves, and to the cloud, so as long as I have an internet connection I can access my work anywhere. (When my tablet died I lost a fair amount of work that I hadn’t transferred across to google docs). I also liked using Writer, because it also autosaved - I learnt from past mistakes that I need autosave. Then, my favourite advice - you just write. Easiest advice to give, hardest advice to follow. Good luck!

My experience is working on an iPhone (a somewhat smaller view area). But it is part of a system. I consider the laptop the “home” and the serious work is done there. The Scrivener file is shared between machines via Dropbox. What works on the phone? Taking notes on the go. (Sometimes I have an idea while on a walk and I use speech-to-text to put it into the notes file.) Reviewing work to date. Not editing; just re-reading to remember how it feels and where I left off. First draft of new scenes. I like to take the phone to a cafe. For that, a Bluetooth keyboard is mandatory. You lose too much screen space and your typing speed goes down far too much. Oddities in the MacOS means I have to go back and fix things like capitalization in dialog but working in a public place keeps me going. What doesn’t work? Well, access to notes is poor. I like to have multiple notes files and reference images and although I can put the important ones inline it isn’t as good as having them on a split screen or a keystroke away. Serious edits. Anything that involves shifting/replacing/saving blocks of text is a chore on a touch screen. Planning. Although I can certainly type ideas into a text file, I block out plots and settings and action scenes and all sorts or other things with scratch paper, index cards, and also software tools like Scrivener’s Corkboard. I’ve tried out a couple of outliner and charting tools as well and they have helped although they haven’t been integrated into my process yet. Research. Multiple tabs, one-click access to browser history, ability to smoothly read index and search pdfs, and of course a large display for images and maps…yeah, priceless. The thing to remember most of all is it takes most of us a 2–4 hour session to crank out from 500 to 1,000 words. So whatever machine you write on, you will be sitting in front of it for a bare minimum of 200 hours, realistically over 600. Whatever perceived advantage in portability there may be in the tablet, that kind of work sounds to me a lot more like at a proper desk in a comfy chair with a nice pair of headphones.

Well, the short answer is, you turn it on and start typing. It is a device. You can write a book on a desktop computer, on a laptop, on a tablet, a phone, or on paper with a typewriter or pen or pencil. The means of putting words down is irrelevant. Many believe that using a pen is the only way. Personally I think an Astrohaus Freewrite and Apple iMac are better for me personally, but it’s all a matter of personal choice. I would ask why you would want to use a tablet, because it’s not the best device. The screen is not ideal (depending on the make and model); typing on a screen will be a slow and uncomfortable process too. If you are determined to use a tablet, my advice would be to use one that can take advantage of a bluetooth keyboard, and invest in the best keyboard you can afford. You need something that you can use comfortably. Also make sure you get a good stand for the tablet, so that it’s at a good angle for you without intrusive reflections. However, I would seriously consider buying something like a Freewrite if you can. It would be a vastly better investment than a tablet if you are serious about writing. Best of luck!

First, find out what bluetooth is. Next, obtain a bluetooth keyboard, bluetooth version 4 is good today. (I have a Logitech k480 and like it,) Take the keyboard home and figure out where the bluetooth hookup is on your phone. Start in “settings” and read down until you find it. Set the switch to on. Set the keyboard switch to on. Set the select switch to 1. On my keyboard there are three selections, so one can run your phone, another your iPad, etc. Start typing on the keyboard until you see characters on your tablet. If you don’t see characters after a bit, check switch settings, switch on is indicated by red sometimes, but on my k480 is on when switch is set to green—also an led goes on. Now you should be set up. Now you type for 2000 hours and when that grueling feat is complete, you have a novel. It’s good to have pads and paper for planning and a tape recorder for when your fingers get raw and bloody and swear at you. You can talk into a digital recorder about as big as your thumb, transfer the audio files to your computer, then convert talk to type. That gives you capability to record anywhere, and believe me, you can pile up a lot of pages that way. You can also use the recorder to record scenes you want to use in your book, like outside and inside for a robbery—stuff like that.

So, you may be young and dexterous with 20/20 vision, in which (whihc) case, writing a masterpiece on a tablet will be straightforward. It would definitely not be for me, though.

There are going to be many different options here since many people write different ways and use different apps etc. My personal preference would be to use Google Doc’s, because then I could make the document on the tablet and easily see it on a computer screen or on my phone as well. As for actually typing it onto the tablet, one of the main advantages of the tablet is it’s voice-to-text option. Therefore I’d be voicing it outloud. If you’re going to type it, consider investing in a bluetooth keyboard. This is all under the impression that you’re still doing this in a personal location. If you’re using the tablet on a bus then I’d still recommend Google Doc’s, and either talk real quietly into a headset w-microphone combo or swipe it out, even if it is slower.

I would say it depends of what type of book you want to write. The actual writing certainly can be done. Considerations should be how comfortable it will be to write an entire book on a tablet. For example, writing a 80k-100k novel on a tablet may not be ideal (although a writer could probably write on any device). And if you want to write a non-fiction book, with graphic images, a tablet may not be ideal. And another consideration is where you want to publish: traditional or self-publish. You would ideally need to have the final manuscript in Word (or InDesign). Or perhaps you want to create an epub. Hope that helps.

While I write and extensively edit in Word on my PC, I use my tablet for reviewing and light editing, thanks to the flexibility of EZ PDF Reader. When I reach a breakpoint in writing, I save and then export as a PDF which I upload to my tablet. EZ PDF enables all the edits I used to do with pen on a printed copy, but legibly, without wasting paper, and with the ability to quickly copy back to Word, usually making additional edits at the time. I open the last saved Word doc version and the PDF side by side and select the text to copy and insert. EZ PDF saves the edits made, including blocks of several paragraphs, although I rarely attempt more than a single page because typing on a tablet is, as others have noted, tedious and slow. But for the kinds of edits I used to do with pen on printed copy, this method works comfortably for me.

Make sure you have enough memory storage or a cloud to upload. Download Microsoft Word if you don’t have it. Choose how you want to input your book. Your tablet probably allows handwriting. You can use voice. You can swipe between letters, or you can type. You can also get a separate keyboard so it is like a computer. So now write and don’t let your tools limit your creativity and DO NOT use it as an excuse.
The same way you’d write a book on a laptop, a notebook, a desktop or a typewriter. You attach a keyboard and start typing.

You can write an entire book on a cave wall, if you want. The only question is whether it’s comfortable for you to write a book on a tablet. Some people prefer typing, some prefer writing by hand. What gets your creative juices flowing, and what is ergonomically comfortable for you? If you’re asking whether you can edit a book from cover to cover and get it ready to print using only a tablet, the answer should be ‘Yes.’ There is software out there for tablets that can help you do that.

How can I write an entire book on a tablet? It’s not something I’d care to do. If I write anything beyond a couple of thousand words I want a big screen, a decent keyboard, and a good word processing app. If you want to do it on a tablet, Jerry Hicks has provided the best answer. Bluetooth and a separate keyboard will do the trick.

Subscribe to Office 365 and download Word and OneNote but choose the platform that works for you - Google Docs or Apple Pages. There are good writing apps too - for novelists but expect to pay a lot of money. These will organize your characters and timeline. Get the best Bluetooth keyboard you can. You can also add a Bluetooth mouse. if you get a tablet with cellular, you will be able to work from anywhere.

I do write on a tablet sometimes. A bluetooth keyboard is an enormous boon. I can’t imagine trying to write anything over a few hundred words without one. Ditto for Word or another quality word processing program. I wrote an entire novella in Notepad once (on a desktop). It was interesting. Also, while I can find it convenient to write a draft on the tablet, I then go to my desktop to edit/polish the finished manuscript. Personally, I wouldn’t like to try that on a tablet.

I’ve done it. I use MS Word. The tablet version is pretty good, though I wouldn’t use it to format the book. I’ve also used Google Docs and that works too. To get the most out of either you’ll need a MS One Drive account and or Google Drive account. The good news is you’ll be able to access your work on any internet connected device.

One word at a time. You may want to make separate files that will eventually become chapters when you get the draft done. Smaller files will be easier to manage. Remember to back them up on a separate device, such as a thumb drive or in the cloud. I recommend having a separate keyboard rather than using a virtual one for straight typing, but them I am PRE-COMPUTER so I don’t much like virtual keyboards. You could, I suppose, dictate it, but I still recommend doing separate files for each section.

Well, it depends if your tablet has the right tools for writing, like the appropriate software (Word could be a good starting point) or even a keyboard. I might believe writing directly in a tablet could be distracting due to app notifications, the Facebook temptation and more but if it is the only tool you have available you should start trying. If you’re not comfortable enough, go to the good old pen & paper and then type the book into the tablet.

One way would be to use voice-to-text, such as Dragon Naturally Speaking’s Dragon Anywhere service, through your cell phone, into a Google Doc. Dragon Anywhere costs a bit each month, however, unlike their desktop software. There may be other transcription tools available (I know Google Docs has something like that built in, for free, though I haven’t tested it).

If you have a good word processor on your tablet (and there are many alternatives available), the process is basically the same as writing your book any other computer. I would invest in a good BlueTooth keyboard though. On the plus side, you are very mobile and can also use your tablet for taking notes and pictures (if you are location scouting). There are also a few apps that help you sort your ideas.

Find an app you like and start writing. A tablet is just another computer, and today’s tablets are more powerful than early word processors, and more than what a writer needs to write. You could use your phone to write a novel today. I’ve typed tens of thousands of words using my phone. I suggest though that you get a Bluetooth keyboard. Big keys for big fingers.

By using a really, really small chisel. Okay, seriously… make sure to save backups regularly, and invest in an app designed for saving and recalling large files. An external keyboard may help, but that’s optional.

No problem. I have often write on an Iphone 8 plus, which is half the size of a tablet. The most useful thing is a small folding keyboard that you can get for £20 or threabouts. I also work with the font size gigger to make it easier to read. You can change it back to a normal print or e-book size once it’s all done. you may need a printer at some stage. It can be tedious pagining through it to proof read, but it can be done.

You can use any available word processor to write the manuscript for your book and submit it to any book publisher in your area. Also, there may be apps available for your tablet that are specifically written for novel or book writers, so you might want to do some research and find the best one with that has the right feature set to suit your specific needs.
Very carefully. Would likely take you much longer than on a laptop. You could get tired of it after a while on a tablet. Think carefully before you decide. Take the plunge when you are ready.
